insomnia.definition: The most common sleep disorder, characterised by difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or achieving good quality sleep

subtypes.sleep_maintenance_insomnia: Waking up during the night and struggling to return to sleep
subtypes.early_waking_insomnia: Waking significantly earlier than desired and being unable to fall back asleep
subtypes.mixed_insomnia: A combination of initial and sleep maintenance insomnia
subtypes.paradoxical_insomnia: Underestimating the amount of sleep obtained despite having a normal sleep cycle
subtypes.acute_insomnia: Short-term, lasting less than three months, often due to stressful life events
subtypes.chronic_insomnia: Persists for three months or longer, occurring at least three nights per week

sleep_related_breathing_disorders.obstructive_sleep_apnoea: The most common breathing-related sleep disorder where airways repeatedly collapse during sleep, causing breathing pauses and reduced oxygen levels
sleep_related_breathing_disorders.central_sleep_apnoea: Occurs when the brain fails to send proper signals to respiratory muscles, leading to pauses in breathing
sleep_related_breathing_disorders.sleep_related_hypoventilation: Insufficient air circulation in the lungs, resulting in elevated carbon dioxide levels
sleep_related_breathing_disorders.sleep_related_hypoxemia_disorder: A drop in blood oxygen concentration levels during sleep
sleep_related_breathing_disorders.chronic_snoring: If chronic and frequent, classified as a sleep disorder
sleep_related_breathing_disorders.catathrenia: Repeated episodes of groaning or moaning during sleep (nocturnal groaning)

hypersomnias.narcolepsy: A rare, long-term brain condition causing irresistible daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks, often linked to lack of hypocretin (orexin) in the brain
narcolepsy_features: Cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness triggered by emotion)
Hypnagogic hallucinations (vivid dreams at sleep onset)
Sleep paralysis (inability to move upon waking)
hypersomnias.idiopathic_hypersomnia: Long sleep duration yet waking up feeling unrefreshed, with sleep inertia and excessive daytime sleepiness
hypersomnias.kleine_levin_syndrome: Characterised by hypersomnolence, excessive eating, and behavioural abnormalities

parasomnias.rem_sleep_behaviour_disorder: Acting out vivid, often action-filled or violent, dreams during REM sleep
parasomnias.non_rem_sleep_behaviour_disorder: Occurs during non-REM sleep, includes confusional arousals, sleepwalking, sleep terrors
parasomnias.sleepwalking: Walking or performing other activities while asleep (somnambulism)
parasomnias.night_terrors: Episodes of screaming, intense fear, and flailing during sleep, often without memory of the event
parasomnias.sexsomnia: Engaging in sexual behaviours during sleep
parasomnias.sleep_related_eating_disorder: Eating or drinking while asleep or partially awake
parasomnias.exploding_head_syndrome: Hearing loud noises as one falls asleep or wakes up
parasomnias.sleep_related_hallucinations: Hallucinations occurring at sleep onset or awakening

sleep_related_movement_disorders.restless_legs_syndrome: An irresistible urge to move the legs, especially during inactivity, accompanied by uncomfortable sensations like tingling, burning, or cramping. Symptoms worse in the evening and relieved by movement
sleep_related_movement_disorders.periodic_limb_movement_disorder: Repetitive cramping or jerking of the legs or body every 30-60 seconds during sleep
sleep_related_movement_disorders.sleep_bruxism: Involuntary teeth grinding and clenching during sleep
sleep_related_movement_disorders.sleep_related_rhythmic_movement_disorder: Repetitive, rhythmic movements of limbs, body, or head during sleep (e.g., head banging)

circadian_rhythm_disorders.delayed_sleep_phase_disorder: An unusual sleep-wake cycle where an individual cannot sleep until much later than considered normal
circadian_rhythm_disorders.advanced_sleep_phase_disorder: Characterised by sleeping early in the evening and waking early in the morning
circadian_rhythm_disorders.shift_work_disorder: Common in individuals working irregular shifts, disrupting their natural circadian rhythm

US_sources.note: US classification aligns with International Classification of Sleep Disorders (ICSD)

daytime_symptoms: Excessive daytime sleepiness, tiredness, or fatigue
nocturnal_symptoms: Snoring, gasping, or choking during sleep
Unusual movements or behaviours during sleep (sleepwalking, jerking limbs)

common_presentations: Daytime fatigue manifesting as hyperactivity (may be misdiagnosed as ADHD)
behavioural_indicators: Hyperactivity (in some cases, opposite to adult sleepiness)

common_presentations: Delayed Sleep Phase Syndrome (late bedtimes 1-4 AM, late awakening)
Poor decision-making and increased risk-taking behaviours
impact_areas: Increased risk of depression and anxiety
Risk of obesity due to metabolic disruption

associated_conditions: REM Sleep Behaviour Disorder (common in those over 50)
Advanced sleep phase (earlier sleep and wake times)

assessment_components: Review of symptoms and medical history
UK_NHS.diagnostic_criteria: Symptoms occurring at least three times per week for minimum three months

questionnaires.stop_bang_questionnaire: Identifies risk of obstructive sleep apnoea
questionnaires.rbdsq_questionnaire: Screens for REM Sleep Behaviour Disorder (score ≥5 suggests probable RBD)
questionnaires.scisd_r: Structured Clinical Interview for Sleep Disorders-Revised

polysomnography.description: Overnight sleep study monitoring brain waves, oxygen levels, heart rate, breathing, eye and leg movements

actigraphy.description: Non-invasive wrist-worn device monitoring sleep-wake cycles over extended period

home_sleep_apnea_test.description: Records breathing rate, airflow, oxygen levels, and heart rate at home
home_sleep_apnea_test.US_note: Results can be uploaded to smartphone app and sent to sleep specialist

multiple_sleep_latency_test.description: Measures daytime sleepiness by observing how quickly a person falls asleep during 4-5 naps

maintenance_of_wakefulness_test.description: Assesses daytime alertness by measuring ability to stay awake during scheduled periods

overnight_oximetry_test.description: Finger-attached monitor measuring heart rate and blood oxygen throughout the night

orexin_a_hypocretin_1_test.description: Cerebrospinal fluid analysis for narcolepsy diagnosis, particularly type 1

blood_tests.purpose: Rule out underlying conditions like anaemia (UK)/anemia (US) or metabolic disorders

pharmacological_principles.general_advice: Hypnotics for short-term use only (maximum 4 weeks including tapering)
pharmacological_principles.when_to_use: Only when insomnia is severe, disabling, or causing significant distress
cautions: Avoid in elderly due to falls and confusion risk

zolpidem.dose: 5mg to 10mg at night (5mg maximum for elderly)

melatonin_modified_release.indication: Primary insomnia in adults aged 55 or over
melatonin_modified_release.paediatric_use: Off-label for children with ADHD/ASD where behavioural management failed (specialist services)

daridorexant.indication: Chronic insomnia where symptoms last 3+ nights/week for 3+ months and daytime functioning affected
daridorexant.condition: Only if CBT-I tried but ineffective, unavailable, or unsuitable
daridorexant.benefits: No association with physical dependency, tolerance, or rebound insomnia

sleepio.indication: Cost-saving option for treating insomnia symptoms in primary care

cpap_therapy.description: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure - delivers pressurized air through mask to keep airway open
cpap_therapy.indication: Standard treatment for obstructive sleep apnea
cpap_therapy.alternative: Bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP) for those intolerant to CPAP

oral_appliances.description: Custom-made mouthpieces worn during sleep to lessen airway blockage
oral_appliances.mechanism: Moves lower jaw and tongue forward

types: Procedures on nose, jaws, or upper airway soft tissue

upper_airway_nerve_stimulation.description: Surgically implanted device stimulating nerve under tongue to open airway
upper_airway_nerve_stimulation.indication: OSA patients who cannot tolerate CPAP

European_ESRS_guidelines.first_line: Cognitive-Behavioural Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) - very strong recommendation
European_ESRS_guidelines.digital_cbt_i: Very strong recommendation for delivery in person or digitally

pharmacological.doras: Very strong recommendation for up to 3 months if CBT-I ineffective
pharmacological.daridorexant: Only DORA currently available in Europe
pharmacological.benzodiazepines_gaba_agonists: Recommended for short-term treatment only (≤4 weeks)

cbt_i.description: Cognitive Behavioural Therapy for Insomnia - structured, short-term treatment addressing thoughts, feelings, and behaviours interfering with sleep
cbt_i.evidence_status: First-line treatment recommended by NICE, ESRS, American College of Physicians, NIH
cbt_i.effectiveness: Improves symptoms in up to 80% of individuals; 90% reduce or discontinue sleep medications

sleep_restriction_therapy.description: Limits time in bed to actual sleep duration to increase homeostatic sleep drive and consolidate sleep

stimulus_control_therapy.description: Re-associates bed/bedroom with sleep rather than wakefulness
techniques: Go to bed only when sleepy
Use bed only for sleep and sex
Get out of bed if unable to sleep within 15-20 minutes

sleep_hygiene_education.description: Information about lifestyle and environmental factors affecting sleep

cognitive_therapy.description: Identifies and modifies dysfunctional thoughts and beliefs about sleep

UK_NHS_recommendations: Go to bed and wake up at consistent times, even on weekends
Exercise regularly but avoid strenuous activity close to bedtime
Reduce caffeine, alcohol, and nicotine intake, particularly in the evening
Ensure bedroom is dark, quiet, cool, and comfortable
Use earplugs or eye masks if needed
Practice relaxation before bed (warm bath, reading, calm music)
Avoid backlit devices (phones, tablets, TVs) before bed
Write down concerns before bed to clear the mind
US_CDC_recommendations: Keep bedroom quiet, dark, relaxing, and at cool temperature (65°F to 68°F)
Turn off electronic devices at least 30 minutes before bedtime
Avoid large meals, alcohol, and caffeine before bedtime
Get regular physical activity during the day
Limit naps to 30 minutes or less, not too late in the day
Establish a wind-down routine an hour before bed

behavioural_techniques.faded_bedtime_with_response_cost: Gradually adjusting bedtime with rewards for meeting goals
behavioural_techniques.graduated_extinction: Gradually separating parent from child at bedtime

children.parent_involvement: Parents are primary agents of change, establishing and enforcing rules
children.when_to_seek_help: If sleep hygiene practices do not resolve difficulties within reasonable time

strategies: Bright light therapy for delayed sleep phase
adolescents.school_involvement: Education about sleep importance, later school start times recommended

specific_considerations: Age-related physiological changes in sleep architecture

recommended_approaches.light_therapy: Timed exposure to bright light for circadian rhythm reset
medication_cautions: Increased risk of cognitive impairment, falls, hip fractures
If medication needed, lowest dose for shortest duration
